article_title: Clinton to drop by 'Colbert' before New York primary
article_text:
Monday's guest @HillaryClinton has a lot of big ideas, and also several smaller ones. #LSSC https://t.co/659q1OBwAK

On the eve of the New York primary, Hillary Clinton will go on national TV to talk about the "small issues" facing the country.

The former Secretary of State will be on the "Late Show with Stephen Colbert" on Monday night — and she's promising to keep it light.

"The past year I've been talking about the biggest issues facing Americans," Clinton said in a promo released Friday with Colbert.

DEMOCRATIC DEBATE: THE BEST LINES FROM CLINTON AND SANDERS

The former Secretary of State will be on the "Late Show with Stephen Colbert" on Monday night. (Jeffrey R. Staab/AP)

"But right now we'd like to take a moment to talk about some of the smallest issues facing Americans," said Colbert, who joins her in the 90-second promo.

Among the topics, according to Clinton, will be the signs on the ladies room.

"Why does the woman on the women's bathroom sign have on that poofy dress? Nobody wears that," she said.

TRANSCRIPT: HILLARY CLINTON MEETS WITH THE DAILY NEWS EDITORIAL BOARD

They'll also talk about health care, but the Affordable Care Act won't be mentioned.

"All Americans should have access to health care," she said. "Ideally whatever Rob Lowe is getting. That guy looks amazing."

Among the topics, according to Clinton, will be the signs on the ladies room. (Anthony DelMundo/New York Daily News)

"Doesn't he?" Colbert said.

The show airs at 11:35 on CBS.
